Oxygen vacancies have been proved to be a key to catalysts’ performance in methanol steam reforming (MSR). In this work, a series of CuZn/γ-Al2O3/Al catalysts with different ZnOx oxygen vacancy content were designed to further understand effects of oxygen vacancies on the enhancement of activation and durability. Through numerical investigation and kinetic analysis, it was found that the migration energy of ZnOx on Cu was reduced by oxygen vacancies, leading to a more uniform core-shell structure and accelerated activation. By analysing the changes in valence and particle sizes of Cu species during different stages of the reaction, it was speculated that more uniform core-shell structure and Cu+ resisted Cu agglomeration, leading to a longer lifespan. Ultimately, by analyzing reduction performance and particle evolution of Cu NPs, a ‘delayed release effect’ was discovered. Graphical Abstract Keywords Hydrogen production CuZn catalyst Oxygen vacancies Core-shell structure Methanol steam reforming Data availability The methanol conversion and Cu dispersion data used for calculation of TOF in Fig.5a are in TOF.xlsx. The input files for structure optimization and migration energy calculations in Fig.9, as well as the optimized structures are in the DFT folder. The reports used in Fig.15 are included in the HRTEM-EDS folder. The .zip file also includes the raw data for Fig.3b, Fig.3c, Fig.4a, Fig.S5, Fig.8, and Fig.14. 1 Introduction To strike a balance between economic development and environmental protection is a formidable challenge facing the world today. However, the use of energy brings environmental damage, especially the burning of fossil fuels, which greatly increases the amount of carbon in the atmosphere and exacerbates climate change. Unlike other clean energy sources, hydrogen (H2) has the reliability required for power generation, has attracted wide attention from scholars [1]. Nevertheless, under the current technology, there exists certain safety problems in H2 storage and transportation [2]. Steam reforming technology can overcome these problems by producing H2 in situ [3]. In addition, it can be coupled with high temperature proton exchange membrane fuel cells (HT-PEMFCs) and applied in portable devices [4]. Methanol is the preferred raw material for H2 production by steam reforming due to its low sulfur content, high hydrogen/carbon ratio (4:1), high volume energy density, mild reaction, and biodegradability [5–7]. The main reaction in methanol steam reforming (MSR) is shown in Eq.(1). The side reactions include methanol decomposition (MD, Eq.(2)) and reverse water gas shift (rWGS, Eq.(3)). (1) CH 3 OH + H 2 O ↔ C O 2 + 3 H 2 ∆ H 0 = + 49.4 kJ / mol (2) C H 3 OH → CO + 2 H 2 ∆ H 0 = + 92.0 kJ / mol (3) C O 2 + H 2 ↔ CO + H 2 O ∆ H 0 = + 41.4 kJ / mol Other possible side reactions, especially at low steam-methanol ratios, include dehydration (Eq.(4)), methanation(Eq.(5)), dehydrogenation(Eq.(6)), formaldehyde synthesis (Eq.(7)), carbonation(Eq.(8)), etc. (4) 2 C H 3 OH → ( C H 3 ) 2 O + H 2 O ∆ H 0 = − 23 kJ / mol (5) 2 C H 3 OH → C H 4 + 2 H 2 + C O 2 ∆ H 0 = − 66.9 kJ / mol (6) 2 C H 3 OH → HC O 2 C H 3 + 2 H 2 ∆ H 0 = + 64.4 kJ / mol (7) C H 3 OH → C H 2 O + H 2 ∆ H 0 = + 84.7 kJ / mol (8) C H 3 OH → C + H 2 + H 2 O ∆ H 0 = + 159.52 kJ / mol MSR catalysts are mainly divided into non-noble metal catalysts (e.g., Cu-based) and group VIII−XII catalysts [8]. Cu-based catalyst has the advantage of high selectivity for CO2 and low selectivity for CO [9]. While group VIII−XII catalysts possess high selectivity for CO as a byproduct, leading to high requirements for treatment of products, which brings difficulties in coupling with PEMFC [10]. Cu-based catalysts are considered as promising catalysts for H2 production on account of its economy. For Cu-based catalysts, different auxiliaries will affect the catalytic behavior in MSR reaction. Among various auxiliaries, catalytic performance can be considerably promoted by Zn species due to Cu-Zn synergistic effect [11]. The causation of synergistic effect has been widely discussed, including induced strain in Cu nanoparticles (Cu NPs), Cu-ZnO interface, Cu-Zn alloy, hydrogen spillover effect and oxygen vacancies. The formation of a metastable "graphite-like" ZnO layer during the reduction process was observed by Lunkenbein et al. [12] for the first time, contributing to understand the synergistic effect between components of Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst. Many studies prove that the generation of oxygen vacancies in catalysts can enhance their performance in MSR by SMSI (strong metal-support interactions) [13]. Jiao et al. [14] prepared CeO2-ZrO2 solid solution coating on carriers by sol-gel method, and prepared xCuO/CeO2-ZrO2/SiC monolithic catalyst by impregnation method. The results show that 5%CuO/CeO2-ZrO2/SiC have the largest specific surface area and the highest oxygen vacancy content, so as to facilitate the interaction between CuO and CeO2-ZrO2. Pu et al. [15] reported that because the ionic radius of Sc3+ is similar to that of Zn2+, so as to be easily embedded in the ZnO lattice and stabilize the ZnO carrier through being located at the surface oxygen vacancies. As a result, Sc3+ is able to restrain the agglomeration of Cu. Cheng et al. [16] enhanced the reductibility of Cu/ZnO catalyst and the Cu-ZnO interaction by doping Al3+. In addition, defective ZnOx sites or Znδ+ at Cu-ZnO interface are the main reasons for the Cu-ZnO synergistic effect induced by Al3+, which is related to ZnO oxygen vacancies to a certain extent. The studies in last five years on CuZn catalysts for MSR are summarised in Table 1. It can be seen that some catalysts can achieve high methanol conversion only above 300 °C, some catalysts possess relatively low H2 production rate, and some catalysts show poor durability. As a result, it is difficult for CuZn catalysts to realize high activities at low temperature, high processing capacity and long lifespan simultaneously. In addition, these researches are more inclined to the study fresh catalysts, and the variations in core-shell structure and valence of the catalysts during activation and reaction are not analysed deeply. Therefore, to enhance the activities at lower temperature, capacity and durability of catalysts for the application of CuZn catalysts, it is critical to consider the dynamic changes during the reaction. In the design of MSR catalyst, not only the selection of active components, but also the structural design will affect the catalytic performance. The γ-Al2O3/Al carrier prepared by anodic oxidation technology has the advantages of homogeneous active components, high mechanical strength and not easy to fall off. In addition, the integral γ-Al2O3/Al has the characteristics of low pressure drop, efficient mass and heat transfer and high flux, which can better meet the requirements of application in distributed H2 production system. In our previous work [35], the loading of Zn in CuZn/γ-Al2O3/Al catalysts was adjusted and the enhancement of CuZn/γ-Al2O3/Al catalysts by oxygen vacancies in ZnOx was demonstrated. More importantly, the encapsulation of ZnOx on Cu during self-activation was obserbed. However, the reason for the enhancement of CuZn/γ-Al2O3/Al catalysts’ activities by oxygen vacancies in ZnOx and effect on Cu-Zn interactions have not been investigated in detail. In this work, a series of CuZn/γ-Al2O3/Al catalysts with different ZnOx oxygen vacancy content were developed. Firstly, the catalytic activities were evaluated and the effect of reduction process on ZnOx oxygen vacancy content was determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Raman and Thermogravimetry (TG). Secondly, the relationship between Cu dispersion and catalyst activities was further analysed. Then the acceleration effect of ZnOx oxygen vacancies on initiation was predicted by numerical investigation and verified by kinetic analysis. After that, the practicality of the discoidal mesh-type CuZn-R80 catalyst was verified by durability evaluation. Finally, the evolution of Cu and Zn species at each stage of the reaction and the SMSI between Cu-Zn were furtherly discussed. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation The monolithic γ-Al2O3/Al carrier obtained by anodic oxidation technique was prepared according to our previous work [36]. The specific process is illustrated in Supplementary Note 1. Zn/γ-Al2O3/Al catalysts were prepared by molten salt impregnation. Zn(NO3)2·3 H2O (99%) was heated into liquid state at 90 ℃, and γ-Al2O3/Al was impregnated in the saturated Zn(NO3)2 solution for 1 h. Zn/γ-Al2O3/Al was obtained after calcined at 500 ℃ for 4 h. After that, Zn/γ-Al2O3/Al with different content of oxygen vacancies was prepared by NaBH4 reduction method. Zn/γ-Al2O3/Al was reduced in the solution with 0.05 mol/L NaBH4 and 0.01 mol/L NaOH for 40–120 min. Immediately after reduction and rinsed with deionised water, the catalysts was treated with vacuum drying at 50 °C for 1 h. The obtained catalyst was denoated as Zn-RX (X = 0, 40, 80,120), where X represents the reduction time. The CuZn/γ-Al2O3/Al catalyst was prepared by impregnation method. After vacuum drying, Zn-RX was immediately impregnated in a 1.5 mol/L Cu(NO3)2 solution for 12 h. After rinsed with deionized water and dried naturally, the catalysts were calcined at 500 °C for 4 h. The obtained CuZn/γ-Al2O3/Al catalyst was denoted as CuZn-RX (X = 0, 40, 80,120), where X represented the reduction time. 2.2 Catalyst evaluation Methanol steam reforming (MSR) was conducted in a stainless steel fixed-bed tubular reactor of 11 mm diameter. The catalysts were obtained by loading Zn and Cu species on monolithic mesh-type γ-Al2O3/Al carriers prepared by anodic oxidation of 30 A/m2. The catalyst (3.0 g) was cut into 20 mesh, evenly mixed with quartz sand with the same sieve and loaded into the reactor to analyze activation performance. The catalyst (3.0 g) was cut into discoidal mesh-type of 10 mm and strung together to conduct durability evaluation, as exhibited in Fig. 1. None of the catalysts were pre-reduced. To demonstrate the reliability of the study, the activity evaluation was repeated on the same batch of catalysts. The difference in methanol conversion and H2 yield was within ±3% for all catalysts. Additionally, the activity evaluation of a new batch of catalysts using the same material was carried out. The difference in methanol conversion and H2 yield was within ±5% for all catalysts. Detailed characterization methods are in Supplementary Note 2. Detailed evaluation methods, calculation of methanol conversion, H2 yield, selectivity of the products and turnover frequency are described in Supplementary Note 3. 2.3 DFT method Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed by the Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP) [37]. The description of exchange correlation functions were based on Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [38] with a cut-off energy of 450 eV. The Brillouin zone [39] was sampled with a 2×2×1 Monkhorst-Pack k-points grid mesh. A vertical 15 Å vacuum space was set along z direction to eliminate the interaction between the repeating images. The climbing image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method was used to determine the transition state, then confirmed by vibration frequency calculations [40]. An iteration convergence with total energy of 1×10−5 eV and residual forces of 0.05 eV·Å−1 was implanted during geometric optimization. Zn3Ox/Cu(111) models of three layers were built to simulate the surface of CuZn catalysts with different content of oxygen vacancies. The two layers of atoms at the bottom were anchored. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of ZnOx oxygen vacancies on the MSR performance of CuZn-RX catalysts Firstly, to discuss the relationship between the oxygen vacancy content of ZnOx and catalytic activities, a series of CuZn-RX catalysts were designed by adjusting the reduction time of Zn/γ-Al2O3/Al. The catalytic activities of CuZn-RX (X = 0,40,80,120) are illustrated in Fig. 2. The results shows that the methanol conversion and H2 yield of all reduced catalysts were significantly higher than CuZn-R0 catalyst. Especially, the optimal CuZn-R80 achieved 96.9% methanol conversion and 95.9% H2 yield at 250 °C. In addition, in the operating temperature range of 250 ∼ 325 °C, the selectivity to CO2 for all catalysts was retained ∼ 90.0%. While the selectivity to byproducts, maintained lower than 6.0% and 10.0% for CO and DME, respectively. Notably, the CO selectivity of all reduced catalysts was slightly lower than that of CuZn-R0 at high temperatures, suggesting the reverse water gas shift (rWGS) was suppressed to some extent. The CO2-TPD was carried out to clarify inhibition of rWGS in CuZn-R80 catalyst, as shown in Fig.S1. The CO2 desorption peak of CuZn-R80 was significantly stronger than CuZn-R0 in the range of 150–250 °C. The CO2 adsorbed on CuZn-R0 and CuZn-R80 was calculated to be 1.46 and 4.63 μmol/g (0.018 and 0.049 μmol/m2) respectively. Therefore, CuZn-R80 has more medium to strong basic sites, allowing it to maintain a higher activity while lower CO selectivity [41]. Moreover, it also indicates that CuZn-R80 has a stronger CO2 adsorption capacity during the reaction. This phenomenon further demonstrates that more oxygen vacancies are contained in CuZn-R80. Fig. 3a shows the deconvolution results of O 1 s XPS spectra of Zn/γ-Al2O3/Al catalyst with different reduction times and γ-Al2O3/Al. XPS relies on surface valence and bonding information for the analysis of surface defects, and it can be used for qualitative and semi-quantitative analysis [42]. The peak at the lower binding energy (530.6 eV, Olatt) is attributed to the lattice oxygen of ZnO and the peak at higher binding energy (532.0 eV, Osurf) is caused by the chemisorption of oxygen-containing species such as carbonate, adsorbed water or hydroxyl groups on the surface [43]. Surface-adsorbed oxygen (Oads) can be used to infer oxygen vacancies because Oads adsorbs onto oxygen vacancies. Oxygen vacancy content was calculated by Osurf/(Olatt+Osurf). After NaBH4 reduction of Zn/γ-Al2O3/Al for 80 min, the oxygen vacancy content increased from 31.8% to 62.4%. Increasing reduction time to 120 min, however, the oxygen vacancy content decreased to 53.2%. From the lattice oxygen content of 37.6% and 46.8% for Zn-R80 and Zn-R120 respectively, it can be inferred that the possible reason is that the reduction process is slow due to the low concentration of NaBH4 in the solution after 80 min, while more water molecules enter the lattice interstices during the subsequent reduction process, increasing the lattice oxygen content. It is reported that the presence of a large number of oxygen vacancies on the surface results in capturing O2 when heated in air [44]. Therefore, the smaller weight loss above 100 °C where water is desorbed, indicates more surface oxygen vacancies. Fig. 3b shows the TG curve of Zn-RX. The weight loss for γ-Al2O3/Al, Zn-R0, Zn-R40, Zn-R80 and Zn-R120 were 9.8, 9.6, 9.5, 7.7 and 8.4 wt%, respectively. The rank of Zn-R80 > Zn-R120 > Zn-R40 > Zn-R0 > γ-Al2O3/Al is in agreement with the XPS results. Fig. 3c presents the Raman spectra of Zn-RX and γ-Al2O3/Al. It can be seen from the Raman spectra that the ‘Zn-OH’ translation modes appear at 510 ∼ 520 cm−1 [45]. The peak intensity of ‘Zn-OH’ translation modes is ranked as Zn-R0 > Zn-R40 > Zn-R120 > Zn-R80. The lowest intensity of ‘Zn-OH’ translation mode represents in Zn-R80, suggesting the least -OH species in ZnOx and the highest oxygen vacancy content, which is consistent with the results in XPS analysis. In addition, due to the presence of zero-boundary phonons, weak peaks appears at 291 cm−1 and 267 cm−1 in Zn-R0 and Zn-R40 respectively, belonging to the second-order Raman scattering of ZnO, are denoted as E2 H-E2 L. The small peaks in Zn-R0 and Zn-R40 appears respectively at 395 cm−1 and 379 cm−1 can be attributed to the A1(TO) mode of ZnO [46]. The peaks shift toward a lower frequency because of the generation of oxygen vacancies [47]. The same tendency of ‘Zn-OH’ translation, the E2 H-E2 L and A1(TO) modes in the four catalysts that gradually weaken and shift to lower frequencies can be observed. The phenomenon indicates that the overall crystal structure of the bulk ZnO is becoming incomplete, therefore, there is an incremental oxygen vacancy content. In particular, the E2 H-E2 L and A1(TO) modes in Zn-R80 and Zn-R120 almost disappear. Due to the irreducibility of Al2O3 [48], it can be deduced that oxygen vacancies are only generated in ZnOx. Consequently, the increase of ZnOx oxygen vacancies promotes the activities. The valence of Zn should vary with distinct degree of reduction, therefore, analysis of XPS Auger spectra of Zn LMM was conducted. As shown in Fig. 4a, the peak at lower binding energy (987.5 eV) is attributed to Znδ+ (0 < δ+ < 2), and the peak at higher binding energy (990.4 eV) is caused by Zn2+ [49]. The peak fitting results are illustrated in Table 2. Theoretically, when Zn species is reduced more completely, there should be more Zn species with lower state, that is, Znδ+ should be increased with the extension of reduction time. The XPS deconvolution results in the Zn LMM region shows that the Znδ+ content in Zn-R40 is significantly increased, while the Znδ+ content in Zn-R80 and Zn-R120 catalysts is maintained at ∼26%, which is not further increased. This phenomenon further demonstrates the oxygen vacancies can serve as electron traps, which are capable of trapping surrounding electrons [50]. This phenomenon further proves the formation of oxygen vacancies on the catalysts surface. The speculated mechanism in the formation of surface oxygen vacancies in Zn-RX is shown in Fig. 4b, which can be divided into four steps. Firstly, electrons is transferred from H- in NaBH4 to Zn2+. Secondly, Zn-O bond is weakened when Zn2+ is reduced to Znδ+, so as to form O-H bond. Thirdly, OH- desorbs from the catalyst surface, and oxygen vacancies are generated in the catalyst, acting as an electron trap to attract electrons in Znδ+. Finally, the electrons in Znδ+ fall into oxygen vacancies, and Znδ+ was further converted to Zn2+. The last step of the hypothesized mechanism can be proved by the Zn LMM XPS results that Znδ+ is maintained at ∼26%. Moreover, ZnOx with electron-rich oxygen vacancies have stronger adsorption ability for oxygen-containing groups. The electronic properties of CuZn catalysts with different oxygen vacancy contents were analyzed by DFT calculations. Fig.S2 exhibits local density of states (LDOS) of Zn3O3/Cu(111) and Zn3O1/Cu(111) models. Comparing Zn in Zn3O1/Cu(111) with Zn3O3/Cu(111), the bandwidth is visibly narrowed in Zn3O1/Cu(111), and the d-band center is shifted from −6.69 eV to −6.63 eV, which is closer to Fermi level. According to the d-band center theory, the shift upward of the d-band center suggests that Zn species with oxygen vacancies enhance the adsorption of intermediates, so as to promote the dehydrogenation of intermediates such as CH3O* and improve the catalytic efficiency in MSR. Work function can also be utilized to indicate the charge transfer performance on the surface of the catalysts. As shown in Fig.S3, except for Zn3/Cu(111), the work function of the Zn3Ox/Cu(111) system decreases from 4.75 eV to 4.73 eV with the increase of the number of oxygen vacancies. The results manifest that when ZnOx is not reduced to Zn0, the oxygen vacancies enhance the electron delocalization on the surface of catalysts, improving the charge transfer efficiency between catalysts and the adsorbed reactant, thus promoting their catalytic performance in MSR. Subsequently, to confirm the influence of oxygen vacancies on the intrinsic active site of catalysts, the activities of CuZn-RX were normalized. Fig. 5 presents the TOF of CuZn-RX in MSR, exhibiting a volcanic trend with the increase of reduction time. An approximately linear relationship between TOF and oxygen vacancy content in ZnOx is observed, verifying the significant role of oxygen vacancies in enhancing catalytic activities. 3.2 Effect of ZnOx oxygen vacancies on Cu species formation in CuZn-RX catalysts Furthermore, it was investigated whether the Cu species were affected due to the introduction of ZnOx oxygen vacancies, especially from the degree of dispersion. Fig. 6 exhibits the surface morphologies of CuZn-RX catalysts and the SEM image of γ-Al2O3/Al is shown in Fig.S4. It can be observed that the pore structure is not damaged by the process of reduction and vacuum drying, but different reduction time brings about distinct states of particle aggregation on the surface, and the particles tend to become smaller with the increase of reduction time. Clusters of about 500 nm is observed on the surface of CuZn-R40, nanorods of 100 nm × 1 μm on CuZn-R80, and small particles on CuZn-R120. To further explore the chemical composition on the surface of CuZn-RX, mapping of CuZn-R0 and CuZn-R80 was conducted. Cu, Zn, Al and O elements were contained in both catalysts, but their distribution was different. As exhibited in Fig. 7, Zn on the surface of CuZn-R80 is more uniform compared to CuZn-R0. For Cu species, Cu is more distributed on the surface of CuZn-R80 in the form of small nanorods, or deep into the pores. While Cu in CuZn-R0 is diffusely covered on the surface of γ-Al2O3/Al instead of entering the pores. Moreover, many studies have reported the effect of NaBH4 on reducing the particle size and increasing the dispersion of active metals in the catalyst [51,52]. Therefore, it can be inferred that with the increase of the reduction time, the dispersion degree of Zn species on the surface will be increasingly higher. For Cu impregnation process, Cu species are more likely to nucleate in the ‘valleys’ of rougher surface [53]. In CuZn-R0, Zn species are more concentrated on the surface of the catalyst and provide rough surface, therefore, Cu species are prone to deposit in ‘valleys’ of Zn species. In CuZn-R80, Cu nucleation is more likely to occur in ‘valleys’ of rougher γ-Al2O3/Al carriers, instead of on fine Zn particles. Therefore, scattered Zn species play a role of "domain limiting", and Cu species are more evenly dispersed accordingly. This fenestration structure plays an important role in the enhancement of activities. The specific surface area, pore volume and pore diameter of CuZn-RX catalysts and γ-Al2O3/Al are summarized in Table 3. Fig.S5a exhibits the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm curves of CuZn-RX catalysts. All the catalysts and the carrier show a type IV isotherm, indicating the presence of a typical mesoporous structure. Fig.S5b shows the pore diameters of CuZn-RX catalyst and γ-Al2O3/Al, which are mainly distributed between 3 and 5 nm. The apparently incremental average pore diameters (Dpore) and the pore diameter distribution between 5 and 8 nm indicate that the reduction and vacuum drying process will enlarge the pores in γ-Al2O3/Al carriers. The possible reason is that H2 produced during reduction process and water evaporated during vacuum drying has a little impact on the pores. Additionally, the SBET results present a volcanic trend with the increase of reduction time of Zn-RX, and CuZn-R80 has the largest specific surface area of 95.0 m2·g−1. The possible reason is that the longer the reduction time, the smaller the particle size of Cu and Zn particles on the surface of the catalyst, which is in accordance with the SEM-EDS results. After 120 min of reduction, some particles are smaller than pore diameter of the carrier, leading to dropping into the pores and blockage of part of the pores. This is consistent with the disappearance of the broad peak of CuZn-R120 from 10 to 15 nm in the pore diameter distribution curve. To analyze the effect of oxygen vacancy content on the crystalline structure of Cu species, the CuZn-RX catalysts were measured by XRD. Previous work in our laboratory has demonstrated the gamma crystalline of Al2O3, as certificated in the characteristic peaks in Fig.S6 [54]. As illustrated in Fig. 8, CuZn-RX catalysts have appearent CuO characteristic diffraction peaks at the 2θ angles of 35.6 °, 38.5 ° and 49.1 °, corresponding to the (-111), (111) and (020) crystal plane of CuO, respectively. The CuO (111) plane is the main exposed crystal plane. CuZn-R40 and CuZn-R80 shows an obvious Cu2O diffraction peak at a 2θ angle of 37.0 °, indicating more electron-rich Cu+ on the catalysts. No obvious ZnO diffraction peak was found in the samples, possibly due to the lower loading of ZnO compared to CuO on the surface of catalysts. The CuO particle size (Dcrystallite) of different catalysts calculated by Scherer's formula are listed in Table 3. It can be seen that the particle size of CuO decreases gradually with the increase of reduction time, which is consistent with the results of SEM-EDS. Cu dispersion and Cu surface area respectively calculated by Eq.(S2) and (S3) are summarized in Table 4. It can be seen that the dispersion and surface area of Cu on the surface of CuZn-RX catalyst increases with the extending of reduction time. Interestingly, although CuZn-R120 has the largest Cu dispersion and surface area, its catalytic performance on MSR is not as perfect as CuZn-R80. This provides some evidence that oxygen vacancies have a greater influence on catalytic activities than Cu dispersion. 3.3 Effect of oxygen vacancies on the MSR activation performance of CuZn-RX catalysts In order to explore the difficulty of migration and encapsulation of ZnOx species on Cu surface in CuZn catalysts with different oxygen vacancy content during self-activation, the migration energy of Zn3Ox on Cu(111) was calculated based on the most stable structure of the same oxygen vacancy number and optimized migration path. The determination of the most stable structure and optimized migration path is illustrated in Fig.S7-S9. The migration energy results are presented in Fig. 9. It can be seen that the migration energy of Zn3Ox on Cu(111) decreases with the increase of the number of oxygen vacancy except for Zn3. Particularly, the migration energy of Zn3O1 on Cu(111) is greatly reduced to 0.0089 eV. The decrease of migration energy suggests that ZnOx requires less energy to form core-shell structure on Cu. To verify the enhancement by the core-shell structure in DFT calculations, the evaluation on activation performance and activation factor analysis of CuZn-RX catalysts were conducted. The increase in the number of active centers in the catalysts leads to a gradual increase in methanol conversion during the activation process, and the influencing factor for the increase in active centers is mainly the formation of Cu2O/ZnOx, i.e., the formation of the core-shell structure. Therefore, formation of catalyst active center is represented by Eqs.(9) and (10): (9) A C u 2 + → k a 1 A C u + (10) A C u + + A Z n O x → k a 2 A C u 2 O / Z n O x Where A C u 2 + is Cu2+ on the catalyst surface at moment t, A Z n O x is Cu+ on the catalyst surface at moment t, and A Z n O x is ZnOx on the catalyst surface at moment t. The numbers per unit area are denoted as S C u 2 + ， S C u + and S Z n O x , respectively. ka1 and ka2 are apparent activation rate factors 1 and 2, respectively. To simplify the model, some assumptions are given: 1. Uniform distribution of active centers on the catalyst surface. 2. The generation rate of Cu2O/ZnOx core-shell structure is much smaller than the consumption rate of Cu2+, i.e., ka2 << ka1. 3. The consumption of Cu2+ during activation is a reaction of level 1. 4. During the activation process, S Z n O x << S C u + , and the rate of Cu2O/ZnOx production is only related to S C u + which is a reaction of level 1. 5. The methanol consumption rate during activation is numerically proportional to the production rate of Cu2O/ZnOx core-shell structure, and the ratio is A. This assumption is verified by the absence of core-shell structure in CuZn-R0 fully apposed to H2O/N2 atmosphere under 225 °C for 3 h, as shown in Fig. 10. The result suggests that the core-shell structure is unable to be formed without methanol. The derivation is shown in Supplementary Note 6, and the relationship between methanol conversion and activation time is shown in Eq.(11) as follows: (11) X M e OH = A ∙ S C u 2 O / Z n O x C 0 , MeOH = A ∙ S 0 , C u 2 + ∙ ( 1 − e − k a 2 ∙ t ) C 0 , MeOH = B ( 1 − e − k a 2 ∙ t ) W here B = A ∙ S 0 , C u 2 + C 0 , MeOH . In order to compare the effect of Cu2O/ZnOx core-shell structure generation in the catalysts on the MSR activation, the data containing the core-shell structure generation rate factor ka2 is fitted by Eq.(11), and the results are shown in Fig. 11. The core-shell structure generation rate factor (ka2) for CuZn-RX catalysts are summarized in Table 5, with R2 > 0.99 for all fitted results, indicating that the activation model with the influence of generation of Cu2O/ZnOx core-shell structure can describe the activation behavior of CuZn-RX catalysts. ka2 values are ranked as CuZn-R80 > CuZn-R120 > CuZn-R40 > CuZn-R0, where the ka2 of CuZn-R80 is increased by 30.6% comparing to CuZn-R0, indicating that CuZn-R80 containing more oxygen vacancies has the highest efficiency of Cu2O/ZnOx generation of core-shell structure. To further validate the computational and experimental results, the difference of core-shell structures in CuZn-R0 and CuZn-R80 during self-activation was observed by HRTEM, as shown in Fig. 12. The absence of core-shell structures in fresh CuZn-R0 and CuZn-R80 catalysts verifies that the core-shell structures are formed during the self-activation process, as shown in Fig.S10. By comparing the lattice fringes, it can be determined that the particles on the catalyst after the self-activation are mainly composed of ZnO(101) plane (0.25 nm) and Cu(111) plane (0.20 nm), as shown in Fig. 12a,b. Despite the presence of dark gray Cu NPs wrapped by a bright gray ZnOx layer in CuZn-R0, it is also able to generate partially heterogeneous ZnOx layers. The possible reason is that the larger particle size of Cu species in fresh CuZn-R0 catalyst (as proved by XRD and SEM results) makes it more difficult for ZnOx to migrate and encase Cu particles during the self-activation process. However, in the CuZn-R80 catalyst, due to the high dispersion of ZnOx in the fresh catalyst and the smaller particle size of Cu species, the ZnOx coating is significantly more uniform, as shown in Fig. 12c,d. Accordingly, in self-activated CuZn-R80, the more uniform core-shell structure brings more Cu-ZnOx interface, which is a crucial catalytic active site for MSR. In addition, the average particle size of Cu NPs in CuZn-R0 and CuZn-R80 catalysts is 8.41 and 6.77 nm, respectively. The uniform core-shell structure in the self-activated CuZn-R80 catalyst reduces the particle size of Cu NPs and enables more concentrated particle size distribution. Huang et al. [55] demonstrated that oxygen vacancies can provide more mobile oxygen species on the catalyst surface, and the theoretical calculation by Li et al. [56] shows that the adsorption of methanol on the defect sites of ZnOx can promote the migration of ZnOx on Cu surface. Therefore, the oxygen vacancies makes it easier for ZnOx to encapsulate Cu by promoting the adsorption and movement of methanol on ZnOx, which is in accordance with the result that CuZn-R80 has an obviously more uniform core-shell structure. 3.4 Effect of oxygen vacancies on the durability of CuZn-RX catalysts in MSR Fig. 13 shows the results of high temperature durability evaluation of discoidal mesh-type CuZn-R0 and CuZn-R80 at 275 °C after 2 h of self-activation. It was observed that over 90% methanol conversion was sustained for 100 h by CuZn-R80, whereas 80 ∼ 85% methanol conversion was sustained for 73 h by CuZn-R0. The enhanced durability of CuZn-R80 suggests bb that the uniform core-shell structure formed during self-activation induced by oxygen vacancies can significantly resist agglomeration of Cu NPs. As illustrated in Fig.S11, significant sintering of Cu at 73 h was observed on the surface of CuZn-R0, leading to a reduction in the Cu active surface. In contrast, no severe sintering of Cu occurred on the surface of CuZn-R80, which remained almost the same as the fresh catalyst. Therefore, it can be inferred that the step-like drop in methanol conversion of CuZn-R0 can be attributed to the sintering of surface Cu particles. In addition, as shown in Fig.S12, only 1.2% weight loss was observed in the decomposition interval of the accumulated carbon at 450–600 °C for the CuZn-R80 catalyst after 100 h of reaction [57]. The fresh CuZn-R80 catalyst also had a weight loss of 1.0% between 450 and 600 °C. Therefore, it can be deduced that no carbon deposited on CuZn-R80 surface after 100 h of reaction at 275 °C, indicating its high resistance to carbon deposit. 3.5 Oxygen vacancy-induced ‘delayed release effect’ from Cu-Zn SMSI Since the valence distribution is crucial for catalyst activities and durabilities, the valence evolution of fresh and reacted CuZn-RX catalysts was first analysed by XPS. As shown in Fig.S13, Cu2+ satellite peaks in all catalysts are located at 940.0–945.0 eV, Cu2+ peak of CuO is located at 933.8 eV. The peaks caused by Cu(OH)2 in reacted catalysts are located at 933.3 eV. Cu+/Cu0 peak is located at 932.4 eV [58]. The content of Cu+ and Cu0 in the catalysts can be further distinguished by Cu LMM XPS spectra as shown in Fig.S14. The higer peak located at 918.8 eV represents Cu0 and the lower peak at 917.0 eV is attributed to Cu+ [59]. For reacted catalysts as shown in Fig.S14 b,d, the peak representing Cu+ shifts towards the lower kinetic energy by 0.5 eV, which is due to the encapsulation of ZnOx layer on Cu+. The fitting results are summarized in Table 6. In fresh catalysts, 11.6% and 13.6% of Cu+ is contained in CuZn-R0 and CuZn-R80 respectively. The higher Cu+ content in CuZn-R80 is consistent with the XRD results. The possible reason is that more Cu-Zn interfaces can be produced in Zn-O-Cu by oxygen vacancies in ZnOx and stronger electronegativity of Cu than Zn, which is in accordance with the FTIR results exhibited in Fig.S15. It can be inferred from that all catalysts present basically the same peak, signifying almost identical functional groups and metal oxides. The broad peak around 3500 cm−1 and the peak around 1400 cm−1 and 1600 cm−1 is attributed to the vibration of -OH or the adsorbed water on the surface of catalysts [60]. The peak around 690 cm−1 is attributed to the Cu-O stretching vibration peak [61], and the peak intensity of CuZn-R0 is significantlly lower than other catalysts. Besides, the peak around 550 cm−1 is the characteristic peak of Zn-O stretching vibration [62], which proves the successful loading of ZnO on all catalysts. The characteristic peaks of Zn-O in CuZn-R40 and CuZn-R80 slightly shift towards higher wavenumber, which is closer to the Cu-O stretching vibration peak. The possible reason is that more Cu-Zn interfaces are formed in Zn-O-Cu due to the appearance of oxygen vacancies. Since the metal activity of Zn is higher than Cu, O tends to be bonded with Zn than Cu, so that Cu-O bonds are easier to be activated. During MSR reaction, reducing H2 and oxidizing H2O and other substances coexist, resulting in the reduction and oxidation of the surface of catalysts at the same time [43]. Therefore, after the reaction at 250 °C, the valence change of Cu in the catalysts depends on the adsorbed species on the surface, namely, more reducing H2 or oxidizing intermediates such as H2O and CH3O. Obviously, more Cu2+ is contained in CuZn-R80 than CuZn-R0, indicating that CuZn-R80 is more capable of adsorping oxygen-containing species during MSR reaction, which is consistent with the DFT results of enhanced adsorption to intermediates by ZnOx with oxygen vacancies. In addition, this result also suggests that CuZn-R80 has an intensifying "hydrogen overflow" effect, concretely, H2 on the surface of Cu species can be more facilely transferred to the surface of ZnOx [63], or directly dehydrogenated, rather than the immediate reduction of Cu2+. More importantly, the Cu+/Cu0 ratio in CuZn-R80 and CuZn-R0 is 7.2 and 12.2, respectively. A higher Cu+/Cu0 ratio in CuZn-R80 suggests more Cu/ZnOx synergistic sites, which leads to a higher MSR catalytic activity. The possible explanation is that the more homogeneous core-shell structures at 225 °C inhibits Cu+ from being further reduced to Cu0. Subsequently, to investigate the reducibility of Cu and Zn species and interactions between them, H2-TPR analysis of CuZn-RX and Zn-R0 catalysts was performed. Fig. 14a exhibits the H2-TPR curve of ZnOx on CuZn-RX and Zn-R0 before and after N2O titration. Due to the unreducibility of Al2O3, the small peak between 350 °C and 450 °C is attributed to the reduction peak of bulk ZnOx. However, there is no reduction peak in the surface ZnOx curve, furtherly demonstrating there exists stable oxygen vacancies which are hardly oxidized by N2O in surface ZnOx. In addition, the peak between 300 ℃ and 400 ℃ of CuZn-RX is the peak generated by reduction of bulk ZnOx, and the reduction temperature is ranked as CuZn-R80 < CuZn-R40 < CuZn-R120 < CuZn-R0 < Zn-R0, indicating that Zn2+ in CuZn-RX can be reduced to Znδ+ at a lower temperature, and the increase of Znδ+ content plays an important role in forming Cu/ZnOx synergistic sites and elevating catalyic activities in MSR. For Cu species, as exhibited in Fig. 14b, three main H2 reduction peaks related to CuO reduction can be observed in all catalysts, where α peak represents CuO with smaller particle size, and β and γ peak represent CuO with larger particle size. Compared with the other three catalysts, the bulk Cu in CuZn-R0 obviously has a wider reduction temperature range, suggesting that the unreduced CuZn-R0 has CuO particles with heterogeneous sizes [64]. The reduction temperature of α peak of CuZn-R80, CuZn-R40 and CuZn-R120 is around 210 °C, which is significantly higher than that of CuZn-R0 (∼190 °C). The higher reduction temperature of α peak indicates that small CuO particles in the catalyst are more difficult to be reduced, and the temperature is closer to that of large CuO particles. This is consistent with the XPS results that more Cu2+ is contained in activated CuZn-R80. Therefore, during the 250 °C reaction stage after self-activation at 225 °C, more small CuO particles in CuZn-R80 are reduced, which is easy to form fresh core-shell structures and Cu/ZnOx synergistic sites, so as to suppress the further reduction of Cu+ to Cu0. It is consistent with the XPS results that CuZn-R80 reacted at 250 °C has distinctly higher Cu+/Cu0. However, for CuZn-R0, due to the reduction of small CuO particles at a lower temperature, the Cu/ZnOx synergistic sites formed has been occupied by part of reactants. When more large particles of CuO are reduced, the larger the particle size of Cu species is, the tougher it is to form a fully wrapped structure. Consequently, formation of more Cu/ZnOx synergistic sites are restrained. Moreover, the more incomplete core-shell structure in the self-activation stage would further lead to the larger particle size of the Cu species in the reaction stage. The above inference can be proved by HRTEM and EDS results of CuZn-R0 and CuZn-R80 after reaction at 250 °C, which will be discussed in detail later. Furtherly, to analyze the evolution of core-shell structure of Cu and Zn species affected by oxygen vacancies during reaction, CuZn-R0 and CuZn-R80 reacted at 250 °C was observed by HRTEM-EDS, as shown in Fig. 15. A large granular Cu agglomerate of ∼150 nm is demonstrated in CuZn-R0 catalyst, while ZnOx layer covered on the Cu agglomerate is less. On the contrary, the deep black Cu particles in CuZn-R80 are significantly more dispersed and are more evidently overlayed by ZnOx layer. Therefore, it can be inferred that CuZn-R80 can form an core-shell structure with smaller Cu particle size and thicker ZnOx layer after the reaction at 250 °C. The evolution of particles on CuZn-R0 and CuZn-R80 catalysts inferred from the above results at different reaction stages are exhibited in Fig. 16. In the fresh catalysts, core-shell structure is formed in neither catalyst, but the dispersion degree of Cu and Zn species is disparate, and CuZn-R80 obviously possess more dispersed active components. During the process of self-activation at 225 °C, part of the core-shell structure and Cu/ZnOx sites are formed, and CuZn-R80 has a more concentrated particle size distribution, smaller particle size and thicker encapsulated ZnOx layer. During the reaction stage of 250 °C, Cu particles in CuZn-R0 grow rapidly due to fewer core-shell structures and is unevenly covered by ZnOx. Contrastively, more small particles and uniform ZnOx encapsulation layers can be found in CuZn-R80, so as to generate more Cu/ZnOx synergistic sites and to achieve a higher catalytic activity in MSR. In summary, the variation in reduction peak temperature indicates that ZnO oxygen vacancies could fetch a certain ‘delayed release effect’. Concretely, different content of oxygen vacancies in ZnOx leads to distinct reduction performance of CuO particles in the catalysts, thus influencing the evolution of core-shell structure and formation of Cu/ZnOx synergistic sites during activation and reaction. 4 Conclusions In this work, a series of CuZn/γ-Al2O3/Al catalysts with different oxygen vacancy content were prepared by NaBH4 reduction method and applied to MSR. The optimal discoidal mesh-type CuZn-R80 maintained > 90% methanol conversion for 100 h at 275 °C. Firstly, the effect of oxygen vacancies in ZnOx on physicochemical properties of Zn and Cu species on CuZn-RX catalysts was measured by SEM-EDS, XRD and N2 physisorption method. Secondly, DFT calculation was conducted to anticipate the migration capacity of Zn3Ox with different oxygen vacancy number on Cu(111), and activation factor analysis was utilized to assess the activation performance of the catalysts. Finally, the evolution of valence and core-shell structure induced by Cu-Zn SMSI was analyzed by H2-TPR, HRTEM-EDS, FTIR and XPS. (1) For the influence of oxygen vacancies on structure evolution of active component, more dispersed Cu and Zn species are possessed in fresh CuZn-R80 than CuZn-R0, a more homogeneous wrapping structure during activation can be formed, inhibiting Cu agglomeration during subsequent reaction. (2) DFT calculation prove that oxygen vacancies are able to reduce migration energy of ZnOx on Cu, enhance adsorption of intermediates, and improve the charge transfer efficiency between catalysts and the adsorbed species. (3) In terms of impact of oxygen vacancies on reduction performance, Zn2+ in CuZn-R80 can be reduced to Znδ+ at a lower temperature than CuZn-R0. A "delayed release effect" exists in Cu species, concretely, small CuO particles in CuZn-R80 can be reduced at the higher working temperature than CuZn-R0, avoiding over-reduction of Cu species during activation. coredata.dc:description: Oxygen vacancies have been proved to be a key to catalysts’ performance in methanol steam reforming (MSR). In this work, a series of CuZn/γ-Al2O3/Al catalysts with different ZnOx oxygen vacancy content were designed to further understand effects of oxygen vacancies on the enhancement of activation and durability. Through numerical investigation and kinetic analysis, it was found that the migration energy of ZnOx on Cu was reduced by oxygen vacancies, leading to a more uniform core-shell structure and accelerated activation. By analysing the changes in valence and particle sizes of Cu species during different stages of the reaction, it was speculated that more uniform core-shell structure and Cu+ resisted Cu agglomeration, leading to a longer lifespan. Ultimately, by analyzing reduction performance and particle evolution of Cu NPs, a ‘delayed release effect’ was discovered.
coredata.dc:title: Enhancing activation and stability of core-shell CuZn catalyst by ZnOx oxygen vacancies for methanol steam reforming
